cartoon corner
Blondie

Name ______________________________ 4. Nutrition labels often provide the Percent Daily Value (%DV) of key nutrients in food. These values are usually based on recommendations for a 2000-calorie daily diet. The %DV lists the percentage of the daily recommended amount of the nutrient that will come from 1 serving of the food.
Use the information shown below for 1 serving of turkey to fi nd the recommended total daily value for fat, cholesterol, and sodium.
Fat 2.5 g (4% DV)
Cholesterol 55 mg (18% DV)
Sodium 60 mg (2% DV) c.  Suppose that you eat 5 ounces of white meat. How many calories would you be consuming? Show 2 ways to fi nd the answer.
d.  Suppose you eat 5 ounces of  dark meat. How many calories would you be consuming? Show 2 ways to fi nd the answer.

3. Generally, there are 9 calories in  1 gram of fat; there are 4 calories in 1 gram of protein and 4 calories in 1 gram of carbohydrates. Suppose that 1 serving of turkey contains 19 grams of protein, 2.5 grams of fat, and 0 grams of carbohydrates.

Describe how you would fi nd the total number of calories in 1 serving of this turkey. Then fi nd this amount.  let’s talK tURKeY 1. A general guideline for buying  turkey and allowing for leftovers is to buy 1.25 pounds of turkey for each guest.    a.  Using this guideline, about how  many people will the 9-pound turkey feed?   b.  If Dagwood invites 4 guests for dinner, what size turkey should he purchase? 2. One serving of turkey is about 3 ounces. One serving of white meat contains about 114 calories; 1 serving of dark meat contains about 186 calories.    a.  How many times as many  calories are in 3 ounces of dark meat than are in 3 ounces of white meat?   b.  Complete: 3 ounces of dark  meat has ___% more calories than 3 ounces of white meat.
from the November 2013 issue of

Edited by david B. spangler, McGraw-Hill Education, and Katie a. hendrickson, Athens Middle School, Athens, Ohio. Classroom  teachers interested in field-testing or submitting a cartoon should contact david spangler, david.spangler@mheducation.com.  The cartoons must include the date and the newspaper syndicate that holds the copyright.
solUtions 1.  a. 9 ÷ 1.25 = 7.2, so about 7 people  should be fed.
b.  Because Dagwood will be eating  too, 5 people will be at dinner. Thus, 5 × 1.25 = 6.25, so  Dagwood needs a 6.25 pound turkey.

2.  a.  186 ÷ 114 ≈ 1.63, so 3 ounces of dark meat has about 1.63 times as many calories as 3 ounces of white meat.    b.  Because 186 is about 1.63 times as great as 114, it is 63% larger than 114; 3 ounces of dark meat has about 63% more calories.

c.  Methods will vary.    Method 1: 114 calories are in  3 ounces; therefore, 114 ÷ 3, or  38, calories are in 1 ounce;  5 × 38, or 190, calories are in  5 ounces of white meat.  Method 2: Solve the proportion 3/114 = 5/x to obtain x = 190.

d.  Methods will vary.    Method 1: Because dark meat has 1.63 times as many calories as white meat, multiply the number of calories in 5 ounces of white meat by 1.63 to find 1.63 × 190 = 309.7, or about 310 calories in 5 ounces of dark meat.  Method 2: Solve the proportion 3/186 = 5/x to obtain x = 310, or 310 calories in 5 ounces of dark meat.  3.  Sample method: Multiply grams by  calories to obtain the number of calories in a particular nutrient. Then find the sum.    Fat: 2.5 grams × 9 calories       = 22.5 calories    Protein: 19 grams × 4 calories       = 76 calories    Carbohydrates: 0 grams ×       4 calories = 0 calories    22.5 + 76 + 0 = 98.5; therefore,  98.5 calories are in 1 serving.
4.  Fat: Solve the percent proportion  2.5/x = 4/100, or the equation 0.04(x) = 2.5, to obtain 62.5 grams for the total daily value.
Cholesterol: Solve 55/x = 18/100,  or 0.18( x) = 55, to obtain about 305.6 mg.    Sodium: Solve 60/x = 2/100, or 0.02(x) = 60, to obtain 3000 mg.

Field-test coMMents

The sixth-grade prealgebra students enjoyed talking turkey. Most students easily calculated that seven people could be fed with a nine-pound turkey. However, a few students did not read carefully and misinterpreted that there were nine people and then looked for pounds. Similarly, for the second part of the question, several students calculated the size of the turkey for the four guests. I asked them, “Does Dagwood eat?” One student answered, “Yes, and you better plan for his wife and leftovers.”

The second and third series of  questions related to calories in food and correlated well with the life science topics that these students see daily. They had many strategies to solve the proportional relationships. The most confusing part was 2b,  because they wanted to use proportions and solve 114/186 rather than realizing that 1.63 times as great meant 63 percent more calories.

The fi nal set of questions confused students. After they realized that they were being asked to calculate the total grams or mg of fat, cholesterol, and sodium, the proportional relationships were easy to establish.
Judy Kraus
Hyde Park Middle School
Las Vegas, Nevada

Because no unit conversions were necessary, this activity was accessible to my Canadian students––despite using customary measures. I appreciated that the questions did not rely on an understanding of customary measures. We did, however, spend time exploring conversions between customary and metric units anyway.
We want to hear from you!
E-mail letters to mtms@nctm.org and type Readers Write in the subject line.

Our students enjoyed the activity, particularly designing their plates from the “Other Ideas” section. Most students solved the problems using rates and ratios, as that was the unit of instruction we most recently completed.
The activity was perfectly aligned  with our Grade 8 curriculum.
Miles MacFarlane
Leila North Community School
Winnipeg, Manitoba

I teach grades 6–8 high-level math groups. This Cartoon Corner worked very well with my seventhgrade prealgebra class. We had just fi nished a unit on proportions, so the students were able to reason out the answers without intervention.

I liked this activity’s real-world examples. The questions were very clearly written and did not require any additional prompting from me. I also appreciated the fact that the activity covered topics from the seventh-grade and eighth-grade science curriculum. The hardest question was 2b. The students wanted to say 163 percent, versus 63 percent, but they understood why they were incorrect.
Machele Lynch
St. Patrick School

Carlisle, Pennsylvania otheR ideas •  Have students make a circle graph to represent how much of the Thanksgiving dinner plate would be used by each type of food.  •  Ask students to bring in  nutrition labels from their favorite snacks or other types of food. Have them ﬁ nd the total DV for various nutrients. Students may also be encouraged to write their own problems from the nutrition labels.
